titleStmt.title: Spontaneous Content of Impressions of Naturalistic Face Photographs

affiliation.orgName: The University of Chicago Booth School of Business
The University of Chicago Booth School of Business

address.addrLine: Rutgers University -New Brunswick Tillet Hall 607, Piscataway

analytic.title: Spontaneous Content of Impressions of Naturalistic Face Photographs

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Social impressions from faces have been studied in psychology for over 100 years. These impressions are rapid, efficient, and consequential. Yet, disagreements about the content of face impressions remain. Across two studies (N = 4,526), we develop a taxonomy of spontaneous face impressions content by applying novel interdisciplinary methods from Artificial Intelligence text analysis to thousands of free-response descriptions of computer-generated faces. We identify a taxonomy of face impression dimensions, and describe their coverage, prevalence, directionality, and correlational structure. We characterize a diverse and nuanced taxonomy of content that, when compared to just the content that dominant low-dimensional models focus on, increases the coverage of spontaneous responses from about 50% to almost 100%. Our results describe general patterns of prevalence, indicating that dimensions from low-dimensional models (e.g., Sociability, Morality, Assertiveness) are highly prevalent, but that alternative dimensions such as Uniqueness and Health, among others, are also significantly prevalent in face impressions of naturalistic face photographs. Most dimensions show a positivity bias, and the correlational structure of the dimensions further supports the clustering of low-dimensional model's content as separate from the expanded taxonomy dimensions. Finally, this expanded taxonomy improves predictions of general evaluations and decision making in various real-world relevant contexts. The derived taxonomy of spontaneous face impressions content is a foundation for further theoretical development and practical applications in an area central to human behavior.

div.head: Spontaneous content of impressions of naturalistic face photographs
div.p: Faces are central to social relations 1,2 , serving as salient sources of impression formation 3,4 . Psychologists have most often studied these face impressions by asking participants to rate faces along researcher-determined dimensions. However, such constrictive measures are unable to measure the spontaneous content of impressions that come to mind upon seeing a face.
Here, we instead use open-ended measures and Artificial Intelligence (AI) text analyses and stimulus generation to provide a more nuanced account of face impressions.

div.head: Impression Content
div.p: Dimensionality reduction of face ratings across numerous traits results in two relatively orthogonal evaluative dimensions: Trustworthiness/Communion and Dominance (related to Agency) 5,6 , even across 41 countries 7 . Communion and Agency evaluations are also wellestablished in other domains, such as stereotyping 8,9 . Face evaluations along these dimensions predict a myriad of socially relevant outcomes. For example, Communion impressions predict healthcare prioritization 10,11 and Agency-related judgments predict elections' outcomes 12,13 .

Recent models have advanced additional dimensions, such as youthfulness 14,15 and femininity 16 . See Figure 1 for a visualization of the theoretical relations between prominent models' dimensions and the proposed taxonomy.

div.head: Figure 1
div.p: Proposed Taxonomy Dimensions in the Literature Note. Relationships between the dimensions as organized in the current paper 14,17,18 and traditional low-dimensional models of face impressions and related domains (e.g., stereotyping). The specific naming of a dimension is relatively arbitrary and aims to avoid confusion between existing models for better theoretical integration.

div.head: Limitations of Established Measurement
div.p: Despite the utility of existing low-dimensional models of impressions, they have limitations. First, because the models are derived from researcher-selected items, they may not capture the full diversity of perceivers' impressions.

For example, open-ended racial categorizations of Black-White mixed-race faces show a much wider diversity of categorizations than often-used forced-choice measures suggest 19,20 . Additionally, researchers often approach dimension selection differently, with some focusing on personality traits 6 , while others include physical traits 21 . Here we incorporate a more data-driven approach to the identification of dimensions, without limiting impressions to a particular domain.

Second, although low-dimensional models aim for simplicity, nuanced taxonomies that more closely resemble complex real-world cognitions add unique value. For example, twodimensional stereotype models (Warmth/Communion and Competence/Agency 8 ) account for only ~55% of spontaneous stereotypes about American social groups. Instead, 13 dimensions are needed to identify over 80-90% of the content of spontaneous stereotypes. Moreover, these additional dimensions (e.g., Health, Uniqueness, Geography) predict decision making when controlling for Communion and Agency 18 . Thus, improving the predictive value of impressions models requires accounting for a larger number of dimensions.
Finally, spontaneous measures allow characterization of impression dimensions not only in their semantic differential direction, but also in their representativeness (i.e., prevalence) 18 .

For example, while perceivers may reliably evaluate how healthy vs. unhealthy a face looks when asked on a scale, this dimension may not arise spontaneously. Dimensional prevalence may relate to accessibility in memory 22 and associations with physical characteristics.
These limitations apply to all low-dimensional face models, but partial exceptions exist.

div.head: Some models have
div.p: involved an initial open-ended task to choose scale items for dimensionality reduction 6 . Others have done limited open-ended analyses (e.g., subjective coding) 23,24 . We build upon these models to provide an in-depth characterization of the content of spontaneous face impressions, resulting in an interpretable higher-dimensional model.

div.head: Limitations of Established Stimulus Generation
div.p: Most face impressions research uses either photographs or 3D digital faces. Photographs are realistic and ecologically valid, but their use is limited by small datasets and privacy concerns. Digital faces on the other hand can be generated in large numbers and are easily translated into face digital models 6 . However, digital faces used so far have been unrealistic and very homogeneous.

Here, we instead use recently developed AI methods to create realistic and diverse digital faces (see Figure 2). This approach draws on models trained on large databases of naturalistic face photographs 25,26 . Our results can be used to generate novel hyper-realistic face models of multiple dimensions 5 . In addition, while almost all prior studies have used relatively small sets of faces (typically, less than 100), our approach can generate a much larger set of stimuli (Study 1 N = 3,022).

div.head: Randomly Selected Sample of 25 Artificial Faces Used in Study 1
Development of a Spontaneous Content Taxonomy
div.p: To develop a taxonomy of face impressions, we initially identify relevant dimensions from the literature (as reviewed above) and using data-driven analyses (as presented in the supplement). Then, we focus on several criteria to evaluate the taxonomy's fit and properties.

The first criterion is coverage, which refers to how many of the face impressions provided by participants the taxonomy can account for. Thus, this first criterion measures the adequacy of the model. The second criterion is the prevalence of the model's dimensions, referring to how often each dimension spontaneously arises in face impressions. Prevalence is a measure of weight (primacy) 17 , with more important dimensions spontaneously coming to mind more often.

Third, we characterize directionality, that is, how high or low a dimension is evaluated in a semantic differential. For example, Morality impressions may be more often about low (i.e., immorality) than high morality.
Fourth, we examine the correlational structure of impressions, providing connections to low-dimensional models.

Finally, we establish the predictive value of the taxonomy. In Study 2, we show that the proposed dimensions improve predictions of general valence and decision-making, above established low-dimensional content.

div.head: Current Studies
div.p: We present two studies using state-of-the-art face AI stimulus generation and text analysis, introducing a rich content taxonomy of spontaneous face impressions (a third study replicating findings with additional variations is in the Supplement). We examine properties of the taxonomy, including coverage, prevalence, direction, correlational structure, and predictive value.

This report is partly data-driven, which provides the necessary structure for making theoretical progress. However, we have several hypotheses. First, we expect that our model will achieve appropriate coverage of impressions (over 80% of open-ended responses accounted for by identified dimensions).

Second, we expect that prominent models' dimensions will be most prevalent, given their established role in predicting behavior 13,[27][28][29] . However, we hypothesize that many other dimensions found in parallel domains (e.g., stereotyping 18 ) will also be significantly prevalent, including socioeconomic Status, progressive-traditional Beliefs, Uniqueness, Health, Social groups, Emotion, and Occupation. Many of these dimensions have been previously studied in face research 30,31 , but are not incorporated into general models of impressions.

Third, we expect that the average impression direction will be high rather than low. For most dimensions this means positive (vs. negative) 32 . Both the Pollyanna principle 33 and positive self-presentation tendencies in naturalistic photographs 34 support this hypothesis. However, it contrasts with negative evaluations in other domains (e.g., stereotypes 18 ). We do expect relatively higher Ability and Sociability, and lower Morality and Health evaluations, given positive self-presentation and previous research on negativity biases for Morality and Health 18 .

Fourth, we expect the correlational structure of the dimensions' prevalence to reflect lowdimensional theoretical models. Specifically, we expect Communion facets of Morality and Sociability to cluster together, and Agency-related dimensions (Ability, Assertiveness, Status) to cluster together 17 . We also expect to find differentiation based on more internal vs. more external traits.

div.head: Data and code available at:
div.p: https://osf.io/pmtxw/?view_only=e817ea93ace74dfab5cb5da28014123f

div.head: Study 1
div.p: In Study 1, we present a taxonomy of content dimensions of face impressions. Then, we examine the dimensions' coverage, prevalence, and direction. Finally, we explore the correlational structure of the dimensions.

In an initial step presented in the Supplement, a more data-driven analysis suggests that the content arising from the participants' impressions largely overlaps with existing person evaluation dimensions and corresponding dictionaries 18,32 . In the main text we focus on the dictionary analyses, which confirm these data-driven results. Power analyses for all studies were calculated using G*Power 35 , and indicated > 99% power to detect a small (d = .

div.head: Method
div.p: 2) effect in a paired samples t-test, an approximation of the planned prevalence and direction pairwise analyses.

div.head: Materials and Procedure
div.p: To generate stimuli faces we used StyleGAN2, a state-of-the-art Generative Adversarial Network (GAN 25,26 ). This AI model was pretrained on the Flickr-Faces-HQ dataset, which included 70,000 high-quality images. The generated faces do not depict real persons, yet they are highly photorealistic and retain the resolution and diversity of the training set 36 . Studies show that humans are barely better than chance in discriminating similar AI-generated faces from real faces (although AI-generated faces may be seen as more trustworthy) [37][38][39][40] .

Each participant evaluated one of 3,022 distinct faces (some faces were seen more than once). We presented only one face per participant to avoid elicitation of content based on comparison with other faces in the stimulus set. After providing consent, participants read the instructions: "In this study you will see a face, and you will be asked to provide the first 6 characteristics that you spontaneously think about when you see this person. These answers will be completely anonymous. We are interested in your immediate, gut reaction to the images.

There are no right or wrong responses. Please use single words (and no more than two words, for example, an adjective + noun) for each of your answers." Then, participants saw the face stimulus and the following instruction: "What are the first 6 characteristics that you spontaneously think about when you see this person?" along with six blank forms for typing responses. Finally, participants completed demographic questions. Table 1 provides demographic context for the stimuli, suggesting significant (perceived) demographic diversity. Note. Ratings ranged from 0 to 100 (for gender ranging from "feminine" to "masculine"; for the various racial categories ranging from, e.g., "Not Asian" to "Asian"; for age ranging from "young" to "old"). Scores derived from models, trained on the same set of faces, predicting various demographic categorizations based on ratings from over 4,000 participants.

div.head: Analysis Strategy
div.p: First, we spell-checked and preprocessed the text responses to remove less-informative details (capitalization, symbols, inflections). Then, we used a multimethod approach 32 to reduce the dimensionality of over 3,600 distinct responses and obtain an interpretable taxonomy (see supplement for robustness analyses using clusters, embeddings similarity, and subjective coding, as well as discussion of strengths and limitations of each method).

Dictionary Coding. Dictionaries were used to evaluate coverage, prevalence, and direction. These dictionaries are word lists that are semantically associated with different dimensions of person evaluation, and have been shown to be internally reliable and valid (e.g., dictionary coding correlated with convergent human ratings) 32 . The 15 dictionary dimensions are: Sociability, Morality, Ability, Assertiveness, Emotions, Social Groups, Status, Beliefs, Uniqueness, Family, Health, Occupation, Geography, Appearance, and a dictionary grouping Other smaller content (plus we subset a Beauty dimension from the Appearance dictionary, given its relevance; see Table 3 for example words in each dictionary). To further validate the dictionaries, we show that they correlate with scale ratings of face impressions as expected (see Supplement).

Prevalence & Coverage. Prevalence coding involved matching responses to the dictionaries (available at https://github.com/gandalfnicolas/SADCAT), such that the response was coded as either 0 or 1 for each dimension, depending on whether the response was about the dimension (i.e., it was in the dimension's dictionary). For example, the words "friendly" and "unfriendly" are in the Sociability dictionary 32 , so a response using either of these words would Direction. Each response was assigned a value of -1 if the response was low on the dimension, 0 if neutral, and +1 if high. For example, "weird" scores high on the Uniqueness dictionary, while "typical" scores low; "friendly" scores high on Sociability, "unfriendly" scores low. For the Beliefs dimension, the endpoints are arbitrary, with high direction indicating conservatism/religiousness (e.g., "Republican"), while low direction indicating liberalism/secularism (e.g., "Democrat"). Given lack of clarity about appropriate endpoints, direction indicators are not available for some dimensions (e.g., for Occupations). For analyses, the direction across each participant's responses for a face was averaged. Direction is related to, but different from, valence (see Supplement).

Correlational Structure. Next, we examined correlations in dimensions' prevalence using text embeddings. Text embeddings are numerical-vector representations of text, encoding information about semantic relations between words and allowing quantitative analyses. For example, words such as "quick" and "fast" have more similar embeddings than pairs such as "quick" and "hair." The embeddings are retrieved from an AI model which "learns" semantic relationships by training on large text corpora (e.g., the common crawl, a vast sample of world wide web content; see https://commoncrawl.org/). Here, we use the SBERT embeddings model39,40. SBERT is a recent model which accommodates context and multi-word responses and returns 768-dimensional vectors for each response.

To obtain these correlations we first computed similarity scores between the embeddings for responses and for highly prototypical dictionary words for each dimension 32 . For example, the words "friendly" and sociable" are highly prototypical of the Sociability dimension (see online repository for list). Thus, we obtained the text embeddings of multiple prototypical words per dimension and averaged them, resulting in an embedding for each dimension. After this, we correlated each response's embedding to each dimension's embedding, resulting in a score of how semantically related responses are to the different dimensions. Finally, we compute a correlation matrix and hierarchical clustering between these variables.

div.head: Software
div.p: All analyses were run using the R 4.3 41 lme4 42 and lmerTest 43 packages. We use estimated marginal means and two-tailed comparisons with Tukey corrections using the package emmeans 44 . We used maximally converging linear mixed models (participants and stimulus as random factors; alternative Poisson models for prevalence did not change conclusions).

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: The proposed dimensions and their top non-overlapping words (in our data), as derived from the dictionaries, are presented in Table 3. Table 4 and Figure 3. We found that
Appearance and Sociability contents were the most common. Emotion, Ability, Morality, Social

Group (e.g., gender, race), and Assertiveness (including dominance-related content) impressions followed, and then Beauty (i.e., attractiveness; a sub-category of Appearance). Largely, these patterns align with our expectation that dimensions from low-dimensional models would be highly prevalent, although some visually salient dimensions were more prevalent than some of these dimensions. We also find support for the significant prevalence of additional content dimensions not covered by traditional models, such as Uniqueness, Health, Status, and Beliefs.

Analyses using data-driven clusters, text embeddings similarities, and subjective coding showed largely congruent results (see Supplement). The Beauty dictionary is a subset of the Appearance dictionary but included separately due to its relevance to existing models. The "other" dimension includes content such as artistic, academic, and philosophical words that fell into smaller dictionaries (Nicolas et al., 2022).

div.head: Direction
div.p: There were significant differences in dimensional direction, F(8, 11,104) = 199.12, p < .001, η 2 = 0.13, 95% CI = [.11, .14] (see Figure 5). In line with our general positivity prediction, most evaluations were about high directions (e.g., faces were mostly evaluated as attractive and sociable). However, Health (e.g., "tired") and Beliefs ("liberal") impressions tended to be low, partially supporting our hypothesis about specific dimensions' direction. Note that this correlational structure refers to the extent to which, when one response is about a dimension, it is also about another dimension (i.e., prevalence). Also note that while correlations largely reflect semantic relatedness, they may also reflect social biases present in natural language (e.g., the word "gay" as a general negative term) 45,46 .

div.head: Figure 5
div.p: Word

div.head: Materials and Procedure
div.p: We obtained 210 neutral stimuli faces from a fine-tuned version of Study 1's model. The fine-tuning used faces from multiple sources (e.g., the FFHQ dataset 26 ) that were coded as "neutral in appearance or minimally expressive" by human coders and automated methods 47 . After the open-ended task, participants saw the same faces and rated each on direction along multiple dimensions, using a 1-not at all to 5-a lot scale. We asked: "to what extent do you view this person as," followed by items (in parenthesis: dimension name): "sociable" (Sociability), "trustworthy" (Morality), "intelligent" (Ability), "confident" (Assertiveness), "conservative" (Beliefs), "wealthy" (Status), "healthy" (Health), "experiencing a positive emotion" (Emotion), "unique/ different from most people" (Uniqueness), "American" (Geography), "physically attractive" (Beauty/Appearance), and "having recognizable features" (Appearance). After rating each face twice, in separate blocks, they saw them again to rate general valence in a 1-very negatively to 5-very positively scale ("In general, how do you feel about this person?").

Subsequently, participants saw each face one more time to rate them across decisionmaking scenarios, using a 1-none at all to 5-a great deal scale. We asked them "Suppose you are in a decision-making position for the scenarios below. How much would you prioritize this person for programs..." followed by multiple scenarios presented in Table 5. Finally, participants completed demographic questions.

div.head: Table 5
div.p: Decision-making scenarios and predictors. To predict general valence we used the glmnet package 48 for regularized regression, reducing overfitting given the large number of predictor dimensions. We selected the lambda that minimized mean cross-validated error for each model. To predict decision-making scenarios, we used linear mixed models (participant and stimulus as random intercepts), with the hypothesized dimensions' prevalence and scale values as predictors of their corresponding decision rating, and controlling for Morality and Sociability (Communion facets), Ability and Assertiveness (Agency facets), and Attractiveness scales.

div.head: Results and Discussion
div.p: Main results replicating Study 1 are presented in Figures 3 and 4, and Table 4, while further details and additional analyses are in the Supplement.

div.head: Reliability & Consensus
div.p: For prevalence variables, test-retest reliability was fair-to-good 49 for all dimensions (M = .62, range: .481-.718). Reliability was higher for direction (M = .85, range: .75-.935), suggesting that given that a dimension comes to mind, it is evaluated more consistently. This is in line with reliability for the traditional scales, which also measure direction (M = .824, range: .771-.918).

This difference between prevalence and direction was expected as what content comes to mind across two blocks in the same experiment is more susceptible to order effects and interpretation of instructions (e.g., whether the same responses are expected across two open-ended replicates).

div.head: Prediction of global evaluations of faces
Prediction of decision-making
div.p: As shown in Table 6, the dimensions from the expanded taxonomy provide value in predictions of decision-making about faces, even when controlling for Communion, Agency, and

Attractiveness. Specifically, all the dimensions from the taxonomy predicted decision making across a range of practically relevant scenarios. The social groups dimension predicting the face recognition scenario was the only unsupported pre-registered hypothesis. However, the closely related Geography dimension was predictive, p < .001. Additional analyses are included in the Supplement and further support the insight that the expanded taxonomy dimensions are used in making decisions based on face impressions.

div.head: Table 6
div.p: Decision-making results. Note. Results shown for scale predictors (item in parenthesis). Controlling for Communion and Agency. Scale items shown in parentheses. For the Healthcare scenario, Health prevalence was significant, p < .001. For Appearance, the "recognizability" scale is shown, but the "beauty" scale was also significant. Geography for Face Recognition shown instead of Social Groups, which was n.s. (see Supplement).

div.head: General Discussion
div.p: We introduce a taxonomy of spontaneous face impressions across two studies and a large set of realistic and diverse AI-generated face photographs. We delineate the taxonomy's properties by establishing its coverage of spontaneous impressions, the prevalence and direction of various dimensions of content, dimensional intercorrelations, and predictive value.
Furthermore, we test the robustness of our findings by using a variety of interdisciplinary methods.

First, we found that traditional content from low-dimensional models 6,24 , such as Third, our results provide insight into the directionality of face impressions. Overall, the direction of impressions was high (and the valence positive, see Supplement), potentially reflecting a general tendency of positivity towards relatively neutral stimuli 33 . This differs from negativity biases in other tasks (e.g., information integration 52 ) or domains (e.g., stereotypes 18 ).

The distinction may lie in face impressions not depending on retrieval of negatively biased information, such as for stereotypes, or perhaps because face photographs do not typically exhibit negative expressions 34 .

Fourth, dimensional correlations support a separation of external features and internal traits in impressions. These correlations also support the facet structure of some dimensions, with high correlations between Status, Ability, and Assertiveness and between Sociability and Morality.

Finally, the expanded taxonomy's dimensions show predictive value. Controlling for low-dimensional model's dimensions, the full taxonomy significantly improved predictions of general valence evaluations of the faces, as well as of various decision-making scenarios. This suggest that the taxonomy can improve our understanding of the consequences of impressions for both general and context-specific outcomes.

In Figure 7 we present a synthesis of our results, showing our proposed hierarchical organization of the dimensions identified here. This organization connects our taxonomy to existing low-dimensional models of content 6,15,16 and identifies distinctions (e.g., internal vs.
external attributions) that may explain discrepancies and facilitate theoretical integration.

To develop the taxonomy, we used a recent face stimuli generation approach 36 . These stimuli were more representative of human diversity than many of the databases used in previous research. Moreover, these findings allow for future computational modeling of faces for stimuli generation, using the various dimensions' prevalence and direction indicators identified.

Given the centrality of faces to social interaction, understanding the content of face impressions has numerous implications. Here, we showed initial evidence of the role of the expanded taxonomy in evaluation and decision-making (in line with previous evidence in the stereotype domain) 18 . Future research may show their role in a much larger set of outcomes, as has been done for established dimensions (e.g., criminal justice, voting behavior) 10,27 . Moreover, spontaneous judgments, as studied here, go beyond previous research by shedding light not only on valence/direction, but also prevalence. Prevalence informs about the weight of a dimension in impressions, and may interact with direction to determine target evaluations, as shown in previous research 18 .

div.head: Figure 6
div.p: High-Dimensional Spontaneous Face Impressions Taxonomy and Properties Note. Proposed hierarchical organization based on a synthesis of the studies across methods and the existing literature. Size of circles indicates prevalence (based on Study 1 dictionary analysis) and color indicates average direction (green = high; red = low; grey = NA). We expect our findings to serve as an initial baseline U.S. model, but also that the patterns presented here may vary based on context, culture, individual differences, and other factors. This should provide a hypothesis-generating opportunity to examine the dynamic nature of face impressions along both direction and prevalence, and a more comprehensive set of dimensions. For example, future studies may measure differences in the extent to which participants vary along the taxonomy dimensions or their beliefs about how these dimensions correlate 53 .

Here, we aim to characterize content without dimensionality-reduction methods that rely on interstimulus variability (e.g., factor analysis). When applied to data across participants, the latter methods may provide misleading conclusions when impressions are not shared equally across participants. For example, whether different participants believe a face is beautiful or moral may depend on the perceiver's social identities 51 . In fact, our results suggest that, although responses were largely reliable within participants, consensus on the content of spontaneous impressions across participants was relatively low (see Supplement). This is consistent with work on partitioning the variance of judgments from faces to variance due to the stimuli (shared) and variance due to participants (idiosyncratic) [54][55][56][57] . Thus, aggregating across participants can mask stable individual differences, resulting in an "averaging out" of evaluations. Because our methods operate directly on all participants' responses, they are not affected by this limitation.
However, other limitations arise, such as the resulting taxonomy including potentially overlapping dimensions (e.g., some dimensions may be more psychologically interchangeable).

An issue, present to some degree in all face databases, is the inability to completely control for emotional expressions. This may induce biases in descriptive analyses, which may be heavily influenced by predominant expressions in the stimuli. To illustrate, photographs may be biased towards positive self-presentation (e.g., smiles), leading, for example, to more Sociability impressions than expected. However, Study 2's neutral faces largely replicated the taxonomy.
Sociability remained amongst the most prevalent dimensions (however, direction for Sociability and Morality was lower in neutral faces; other differences in prevalence, such as slightly lower

Morality and higher Assertiveness occurred for neutral faces). Furthermore, multiple real-world contexts may also reflect self-presentational tendencies, including face impressions in social media, CVs, and politician photographs, among others, with relevant implications (e.g., biases in hiring). In fact, naturalistic photographs have several advantages compared to standardized stimuli, including potential higher ecological validity 58 .
In general, we advocate a multi-method approach to balance methodological strengths and limitations (see Supplement for highly congruent replications across methods).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Faces are a significant source of information in social interactions. Here, we describe the coverage, content prevalence, directionality, dimensional intercorrelations, and predictive value of a taxonomy of spontaneous impressions of naturalistic face photographs. We used cuttingedge interdisciplinary methods from AI language models and computer vision to provide an account of impressions of a highly diverse and realistic set of human faces. A taxonomy of face impressions that is more comprehensive than current low-dimensional models is a foundation for further theoretical development and practical applications in an area central to human behavior.

figure.figDesc: receive a score of 1 on Sociability. Responses could be coded into multiple dictionaries if related to more than one dimension. Responses not included in dictionaries were coded as "No match", and this variable was used to quantify coverage. For prevalence analyses, we averaged each participant's responses for each dimension (resulting in a percentage of a participant's responses about the dimension per face). The predictor variable was a categorical indicator for each dimension and the outcome was the response rate for the corresponding dimension.

figure.figDesc: Direction of Dimensions of Face Impressions Note. Panels: a) Study 1, b) Study 2. Error bars indicate Standard Errors. Due to its relevance, Beauty is shown separately, but it is also counted within the overarching Appearance dimension. Direction computed from dictionaries only. text embeddings prevalence correlations aligns with an overall internal vs. external distinction of impressions, with group membership and other mixed categories overlapping with both internal and external features. The correlation patterns also support the facet structure of Communion (Morality + Sociability) and Agency (Ability + Assertiveness, here including the highly related Status dimension 8 ), in line with low-dimensional models.

This neutral face model achieved acceptable quality levels, comparable to Study 1's model. Each participant rated 3 faces, twice across two blocks. Faces were presented one at a time, in random order (each face seen by an average of 20 participants). Participants saw the same instructions as in Study 1, except that they were informed they would see each face twice, and we asked them to "Please type as many characteristics as you think about," followed by 10 text boxes.

them about political polarization Beliefs Income …aimed at providing them with additional sources of income Status Analysis Strategy Study 2 includes all the analyses described in Study 1 (aggregation was based on responses provided per participant). To compute reliability, we ran mixed models with the variable of interest as outcome, an intercept, and participant, stimulus, and participant-bystimulus random factors. Reliability is the sum of all the intraclass correlation coefficients (ICCs), except the residual.

figure.head: First, a baseline
figure.figDesc: regularized model using scales for facets of Communion, Agency, and Attractiveness as predictors resulted in an R 2 = .525. A model including all the scale items as predictors, covering additional dimensions such as Health, Emotion, Beliefs, Status, Uniqueness, Geography (foreignness), and Appearance, increased variance explained (R 2 = .554). This suggests that even for a broad variable such as global evaluations, the expanded taxonomy improves variance explained (see Supplement for additional supportive tests, including ANOVA comparisons).

Communion and Agency, accounted for approximately half of impressions. On the other hand, the taxonomy we introduce, including dimensions such as Emotions, Social groups, and Uniqueness, among others, resulted in coverage of over 95% of spontaneous impressions. Gaps in our understanding of the content of impressions can lead us to ignore relevant evaluations that may affect behavior.Second, prevalence results point at differences in the primacy17 of various dimensions in spontaneous face impressions, as some dimensions come to mind more often than others. In line with low-dimensional models, Morality and Assertiveness were amongst the most prevalent dimensions. On the other hand, in contrast with group stereotypes50,51 , Beliefs was one of the least prevalent dimensions. The taxonomy also helps differentiate dimensions that have often been examined in conjunction in the past (e.g., Sociability and Morality as facets of Communion), but that show a clear dissociation in face impressions (e.g., Sociability is more prevalent than Morality content).

row.cell: Participants were 3,145 Amazon Mechanical Turk workers (after removing 13
participants for not following instructions). Participants' mean age was 38.18 years, most
identified as women (53.8%; 45.2% men) and White (71.6%; 8.5% Asian; 8.5% Black; 5.2%

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: Demographic Categorization Ratings of Stimuli, based onPeterson et al. (2022)

figure.head: Table 3 Non
figure.figDesc: CoverageIn line with our hypothesis, the dimensions measured by the dictionaries had very high coverage: The 15 dictionaries accounted for over 96% of the total responses and over 80% of distinct responses. The remaining unaccounted-for responses tended to be largely idiosyncratic or involved grammatical mistakes or nonsense responses. In contrast, looking only at the two (Communion & Agency 6 ) or three (adding Beauty 24 ) most established content dimensions, responses accounted for were only 47.5-54.6%.
figure.note: -overlapping Top Words and Frequencies for the Dimensions, Study 1Prevalence Given that the taxonomy achieved high coverage, we proceed to present the prevalence of the taxonomy dimensions. Tests comparing the various dimensions' response rates were significant, F(16, 53448) = 1,077.7, p < .001, η 2 = 0.244, 95% CI = [.238, .250], see

figure.note: Note. Mean values are proportions of responses (ranging from 0 to 1). Values in a column sharing a superscript are not significantly different from each other, p > .05.

figure.figDesc: Embedding Prevalence Scores Correlations and Hierarchical Cluster, Study 1 Study 1 had some limitations. For example, while presenting only one face per participant has the advantage of minimizing contrast or assimilation effects due to rating a face along other faces, it prevents computation of reliability measures. To balance strengths and limitations, Study 2 asks for impressions of multiple faces, rated twice per participant. Study 2 presents evidence for the taxonomy's predictive value. To examine the role of dimensions beyond those from traditional low-dimensional models, we examine improvements in prediction of global evaluations of faces. Furthermore, beyond broad predictions of global evaluations of faces, a higher-dimensional taxonomy may hold promise in providing information about evaluations and decision-making in specific, yet relevant, contexts, where low-dimensional models may be too broad or not cover the relevant dimensions. In Study 2, we test predictions of decision-making in important real-world based scenarios. Amazon Mechanical Turk workers (after exclusion of 28 participants for responding too quickly and having negative reliability). Participants' mean age was 43.14 years; most identified as men (49.5%; 48.2% women) and White (68.9%; 15.9%Black; 7.8% Asian; 5% Multiracial; 8.4% Hispanic).

row.cell: Additionally, faces in Study 1 may be representative of internet face photographs, but may be
particularly susceptible to positive self-presentation (e.g., smiles). In Study 2 we address this
issue by including only neutral faces. Study 2 also allows participants to provide as many
impressions as preferred (up to 10), to examine robustness to instruction variation.
Unless noted, Study 2 used the same methods as Study 1. Study 2 was preregistered
